q.a: ah, as you can see, i think this perfectly illustrates why it is best to wait at least a year or two before composing the reality videos. those ones you saw, those were probably composed within a month or two of the original recording, and so i didn't have the proper perspective to know that the idea of doing an album was a very fleeting idea. looking at it now, seeing the big picture, at least the way i feel about it now, music albums don't work for me and they've never worked for me. whenever i receive music on an album, for some reason i always think i hate all the songs. but whenever i receive songs individually, there is a much higher chance i will like and appreciate that 1 song. i can't remember exactly why i thought an album would be a good idea at that time. but my point is that if i were assembling reality videos from that time period, now, i would obviously skip all the stuff where i am talking about making an album, so that way i wouldn't have to explain how or why i changed my mind
q.q: i believe in some reality videos (probably between 2014-2016 i think) you said you were working towards an album, or wanted to start an album, maybe thinking about making one? did you stop being interested in making an album at some point? or are you still just as interested as before?

q.a: i probably was confusing it with something with a bit more of a story line
q.q: do you remember why you wanted to make an album?

q.a: right but if it's not what i want to make, then i'm not going to make it good. that's the golden rule of content
q.q:
do you still want to make an album at some point?
i know you've said you thought albums are boring, but i think you'll find that a lot of your audience would like an album by you.

q.a: i have never had a good experience with an album. i think it's just too many new songs to digest at one time. it seems very fatiguing and it always seems like there's nothing good on the album. where as if those songs were released individually, in most cases i probably would have liked almost all of them. it is still my belief that songs are not at their strongest when grouped together with several other songs and no other connecting tissue such as visual or story or both, or more. in other words, what i'm saying is, and i'm sure i have said it here 100 times before, i think the key to making albums be the best they can be would be to make it so much more than an album that it would no longer be considered an album
q.q:
you could go about making it once you have an efficient schedule and have gotten to the point where you will be ready enough and confident enough to start uploading videos/songs/music videos like you would releasing all the songs as singles, where you could have a music video for each song, and just release both videos and songs, or maybe the album as all the music videos put together. or you could just make all the music videos a nd songs, but release the album as audio first (with the cover obviously if you make an album cover) and then either individually release all the music videos at certain intervals (I.E. every day until the music videos are all uploaded, every few days, every week, month. probably not longer than a month between releases if its already made.) or release all the music videos after the audio. or maybe you could take a few of the songs you make (say, in the future you've released 11 songs with music videos in like 6 months) and you could make a cover, and call that an album.

p.s. i would really enjoy an album from you, especially if all of the songs are similar within your style.

q.a: it has to be developed over a very short period of time, at an extremely young age. i should also mention that it is not important to good musicianship, and might likely distract from it. it also has a misleading name 'perfect pitch', because it has nothing to do with whether you can sing or play in tune. 'absolute pitch' might be a slightly clearer name for it. absolute pitch is mostly not at all what gives music its power. nearly 100% of the power of music comes from the relative relationships between pitches. and the good news is that those can be mastered at later ages, although it still helps to start young but it's not a deal breaker if you don't. where as with absolute pitch, you really can't get there unless you have it locked in by age 6. but as i said before, absolute pitch is hardly important for excellent musicianship, and might even be misleading or distracting

q.q: i love the word dang. it's the best non-curse curse word substitute (for damn) of which im personally aware. we can go through the others: frick, frig, shiz, heck, etc. heck is okayish but the rest are dumpster substitutions for babies exclusively --  because only people barred from the good stuff would feel obliged to reach for these extremely lesser knockoffs. nobody is ever going to take down king fuck. nobody's ever TRYING to come for ass, and all of its versatility (dumbass, badass, smartass). and it's not even that damn is bad. damn has its own incredibly powerful energy, bringing a unique severity and dare i say solemnity to the table. but dang manages to create a space for itself that goes beyond mere substitution. dang conjures an entire mythos of cowboys and fathers hitting their thumbs with hammers while trying to nail together wooden planks. "dangit" manages to be more than an avoided "damnit," a mere damnit-lite. there's such a  vast am ount of beauty in the word dang that i truly don't understand. how did it get like this, do you think, bill? why can't the other fake curses do this well in the vernacular?

q.q: building off that person's chord-finding question, what are your recommended next steps after achieving the skill of being able to play a note that you hear on your instrument? I can do that, but my issue with chords is that I'm never 100% sure whether the chord I've transcribed has too many notes or not enough. When I'm in the process of adding notes to the chord, there are definitely some that are obviously not present in the chord. Other notes however sound "good" but I wonder if they are actually there or are just "compliant" with the chord and are effectively coloring it in a way that sounds nice. As for not having enough notes in the chord, that is a mystery to me. Maybe that problem isn't as bad though because at a certain point you've gone through all the notes in the scale allotted to that chord in a certain range of the piano and hopefully any significantly lower/higher duplicates of those notes would be obvious to pick out.

q.a: computers don't need much water at all, do they
q.q:
Comparing Io to Europa, scientists assume Europa is more likely to host life because there is water there, but that water is likely completely homogeneous in temperature, providing little energy for any life, and even less places for that energy to go.

Io is basically one large Yellowstone. Each of those geisers and vulcanic cauldrons has such a vast contrast in temperature that life may just fluke into existence like it did here.

And those are in my opinion some of the less promising bodies. Jupiter herself is so vast and full of anomalies that there could very well be life in there, too.

So basically, is water essential to life, or is water essential to Terran life.

q.a: hm .... it seems like most of your information is wrong. 'stuck in a rut' the audio recording was made in 2005. it definitely wasn't put on itunes until at least 2015, because i didn't have the abilitiy to put things on itunes until then. but i hopefully dated it correctly, based on when it was made (2005). as of 2005 and the many years before that, i was fully capable of writing and recording instrumental music, but the whole 'words' part of it was really not figured out yet. 'i'm stuck in a rut' was essentially all i could fathom at that time. although meanwhile i was going absolutely bonkers via text editors. which i recommend to anyone who is trying to figure out which way is which. my strategy in general was to see if i could deconstruct the entire universe and how it works. that was just the only way i could get my head around the full game of songwriting, including any and all musical/linguistical things i thought i could and might be capable of. somewhere around 2009 i think i found myself ready to get into the full songwriting game, but it still took a few more years after that to get the recording schemes, and the writing schemes, further organized. videos, is yet an entirely separate piece of the puzzle which i had to sort of put together from scratch .... which i am actually doing again now, as it turns out
q.q: I don't remember if this got asked before, but why was there such a long pause between "stuck in a rut" being uploaded to iTunes and your next single being put up? And how did "stuck in a rut" come about anyways? Given it's from all the way back in 2008 I'm curious the events surrounding it.

q.q: So, I usually write instrumental music. Y'know, programmatic/soundtracky kinda stuff. But right now I'm working on a song that requires lyrics. As it turns out, lyrics are fuckin' DIFFICULT. The music I usually write isn't very self-expressive; I'm more interested in seeing what I can bring to life in the mind of the listener by using different sounds, tones, and techniques. Writing lyrics feels more akin to public speaking. A very personal, intimate form of public speaking.

q.a: the funny thing is that you can use absolutely anything. there is so much room to do things that no one has ever done before. just to focus on the word side of things, for you what i would recommend is, open up a text file. and go bonkers every day for 3 meals on a regular basis. that's just to get in the mood. when it comes time to actually do musical lyrics, i recommend coming up with it musically. and if you have been going bonkers in the text lately, i think you will be on your best game, linguistically and otherwise

q.q: Biggly advice time, how do you structure the planning of a video? I've been meaning to get a script down because I think I'm a bit of a funny feller, but I can't for the life of me plan individual tasks out. Like I can physically edit videos and do all the production side of stuff, but putting pen to paper at all seems impossible.

q.a: yes, for you i recommend doing shorter projects. and then if you are still even slightly overwhelmed, then i would still recommend even shorter projects. if you don't believe me, check out the videos i was doing during 2014 and 2015. if i could have started with something like 'history of japan' first, believe me i would have. but i was going through the exact same thing as you. building a world is a mindfuck. it can be done, but you gotta work your way up. i personally am still working my way way up, there's a long way to go still. but yeah, if you want the secret to unlocking multiple huge mountains, the answer is to start brainlessly small and simple. this trick has worked for me over and over and over and over again, and i am doing it again now as we speak
q.q:
I've managed bigger projects before but something about writing a script seems difficult to organise

Also being sad and lazy doesn't help but I'm almost over that.

q.q: hi bill! i want to start making videos, but i don't know what software i should use. i have tried using blender, but it is very confusing.

q.a: what you must do, for your very first video making experience, is: do NOT get a heavy program. do not get a big heavy huge expensive complex program. trust me, you will choke on brain fog and take a high amount of confused naps. What you must do is, use the absolute simplest thing you can get your hands on. like really simple. really really really simple. trust me, i have been through this, both ways, many times before. heck i am still going through it, especially throughout 2019 and 2020. You must use the most simple and basic thing you have. It's best to actually use something you already have, to further eliminate confusion and complications. Making videos is potentially the entire world at your fingertips. So that means you are going to have to take some desperate measures and precautions to NOT be overwhelmed at the start. staring at the whole universe of possibilities right at the start is enough to cause total brain failure. i wish i could tell you how many times i have been through both sides of this before. this is so important

q.a: this may not be what you want to hear, but you are going to find some music that you really enjoy which has the qualities you want. OR, if it does not exist, then you are going to have to invent something that's never been done before. so IF that is the case, then i would recommend finding things that you enjoy that seem inventive and new in other ways than the ways you might do, to at least familiarize with the fun and glory of being inventive. A good place to start if you hate all the music you've ever heard, is to start by deliberately trying to make something as different from that as possible, and then hone it in from there. you might have more fun than you expected

q.q: I find myself in a conundrum often, where someone says something, and I can perceive (perhaps incorrectly) the type of reaction they want to get from saying said things.

q.a: they want to be talking to the real you. so the best thing you could possibly do is just be there with them in that moment. if you are unable to process what they said in any other way, blank stares are fine too, those can often produce a great deal of humor, among many other interesting things, as the time unfolds
q.q: And it kinda shortcircuits my brain. where I happen to believe I know what they want to hear, yet I don't naturally tend towards that reaction. Which leaves me feeling like i let them down. Do you have any tips for dealing with those moments?

q.a: i personally feel let down and get a very empty feeling when it seems like someone is trying to tell me just what i want to hear. i want to be enthralled, confused, surprised, enriched, or even underwhelmed by something from them that i did not expect to hear. so in your situation, i would take every opportunity to avoid what you 'think' they 'want to hear.' if they really knew exactly what they wanted to hear, then there are some chat bots that would be a better fit for them
q.q: Where you just want to react as you would, regardless of what you may assume is the desired response to their call. It's like I feel that i let them down whenever i dont give the response i believe they are looking for.

q.a: astrology is not communication, it's just a time keeper. it's like the hands on your clock. is the minute hand asking the hour hand where it's supposed to be? hell no. it is at minute 57 because it just came from minute 56 a minute ago, and that's just how fast it's going. and the hour hand moves at its own steady pace as well. the day follows the clock nearly exactly, but is that because the day is listening to the clock? hell no. what happened was, the clock was formed based on the day. day was first. the sun was first, that was the first thing here. and the rhythms in the solar systsem are actually even harder to interrupt than clock hands
